item.title: Picture Prompt: Seasonal Depression
item.description: Do the darker, colder days affect your mood? What do you do about it if so?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: At This College, the English Dept. Is Out. ‘Human Narratives’ Is In.
item.description: At Montclair State University in New Jersey, a departmental restructuring plan is igniting concerns about the future of the humanities.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman

item.title: NYT Spelling Bee Answers for Nov. 19, 2025
item.description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
item.dc:creator: New York Times Games

item.title: Trump Administration Gives Three Mile Island Nuclear Project $1 Billion Loan
item.description: The Pennsylvania site, shorthand for the dangers of nuclear power after a 1979 meltdown, is set for revival under a deal to power Microsoft data centers.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman

media:content.media:description: Constellation’s nuclear power plant, called the Crane Clean Energy Center, on Three Mile Island near Middletown, Pa. earlier this year.

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince Dines With Trump at the White House
item.description: President Trump stood shoulder-to-shoulder with Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman of Saudi Arabia during a White House dinner on Tuesday. The room was packed with leaders from several industries.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Celebrates ‘Epstein Rockin’ Eve’
item.description: “Stay up for a ball drop you’re going to want to miss,” the “Late Show” host said as Congress voted for the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘umbrage’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 58 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: umbrage
item.description: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: 6 obras de arte que podrían predecir el mercado
item.description: Un inodoro de oro, fósiles de dinosaurio y un cuadro de Frida Kahlo se encuentran entre las obras más esperadas en las subastas de otoño.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small, Julia Halperin and Tim F. Schneider

media:content.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A viewer crouches next to Maurizio Cattelan’s artwork-as-loo.

item.title: La esposa de una astronauta se declara culpable de alegar falsamente un delito desde el espacio
item.description: Summer Worden admitió haber mentido a agentes federales cuando acusó a su pareja, la astronauta Anne McClain, de acceder ilegalmente a su cuenta bancaria desde la Estación Espacial Internacional.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

media:content.media:description: Anne McClain se encontraba en la Estación Espacial Internacional en 2019 cuando su esposa, de la que estaba separada, la acusó falsamente de acceder ilegalmente a su cuenta bancaria.

item.title: ¿Pasta al doble de precio? Algunos productores italianos enfrentan aranceles enormes en EE. UU.
item.description: Una investigación del Departamento de Comercio podría imponer tarifas prohibitivas a marcas italianas, desde Barilla hasta Rummo, desatando temores de que la pasta auténtica desaparezca de las estanterías estadounidenses.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Gianni Cipriano

media:content.media:description: Mezze penne rigate pass along a rolling conveyor after the drying phase.

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Showed That China Can Stand Up to America
item.description: His ill-conceived tariff war exposed U.S. vulnerabilities, strengthened China’s leverage and undermined America at a pivotal time.
item.dc:creator: Rush Doshi

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Mr.Nelson design; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Harvard Opens New Investigation Into Summers and Epstein
item.description: The university is reviewing newly released emails between convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and former Harvard President Lawrence H. Summers, among other people at the institution.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

media:content.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Lawrence H. Summers, the former president of Harvard, said he was stepping away from public commitments.

item.title: Dubai Watch Week Opens With a New Site and 90 Brands
item.description: The fair’s 10th year also will include a 75th anniversary gala for Ahmed Seddiqi, the regional retailer that was a driving force behind its creation.
item.dc:creator: Ming Liu

media:content.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: This year’s Dubai Watch Week will be held at Burj Park, adjacent to Dubai Mall and at the foot of the world’s tallest building, Burj Khalifa

item.title: See How Home Insurance Premiums Are Changing Near You
item.description: A climate ‘shock’ in the insurance market has started to affect home prices in areas most exposed to wildfires and hurricanes, new research shows.
item.dc:creator: Mira Rojanasakul and Claire Brown

item.title: Google quiere revolucionar la IA con el lanzamiento de Gemini 3
item.description: Gemini 3 mejora la capacidad de su predecesor para crear programas de software, organizar el correo electrónico y ayudar a las empresas a analizar documentos.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz

media:content.media:credit: Andria Lo para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Google afirmó que la información generada por Gemini 3 tenía una precisión del 72 por ciento.

item.title: Smoking Weed Could Lead to Less Drinking, New Study Suggests
item.description: In a makeshift bar on a college campus, researchers studied how smoking cannabis affected alcohol consumption.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Quote of the Day: President Offers Pomp and Praise in Welcoming Saudi Crown Prince
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 19, 2025.

item.title: Rising Home Insurance Premiums Are Eating Into Home Values in Disaster-Prone Areas
item.description: Changes in the insurance market have started to affect home prices in the most disaster-prone areas, new research finds, pushing some homeowners’ finances to the breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown and Mira Rojanasakul

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 19, 2025.

item.title: Europe’s Chip Dreams Confront Business Realities
item.description: European chipmakers need TSMC’s help to grow their own semiconductor supply chain, but the chip giant’s Taiwanese suppliers find Europe a tough place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu

media:content.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: TSMC is teaming up with European chipmakers to build a factory near Dresden, Germany, as Europe’s need to make its own chips has grown more pressing.

item.title: In the A.I. Race, Chinese Talent Still Drives American Research
item.description: Although some Silicon Valley executives paint China as the enemy, Chinese brains continue to play a major role in U.S. research.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Eli Tan

media:content.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: New research shows just how important Chinese engineering talent still is to Silicon Valley companies.

item.title: The 2025 Michelin Stars Awarded for the Northeast and Chicago
item.description: A restaurant in New York gets three stars, and Philadelphia and Boston are included for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Meghan McCarron

media:content.media:credit: Marissa Alper for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The chef Keiji Nakazawa’s New York City restaurant, Sushi Sho, was the only new three-star restaurant in this year’s Michelin Guide.

item.title: ‘This World of Tomorrow’ Review: Tom Hanks Is Back in Town
item.description: The movie star plays a man from the future at the 1939 New York World’s Fair in an adaptation of some of his stories. Kelli O’Hara shines as his love interest.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes

media:content.media:description: Tom Hanks, Kayli Carter and Kelli O’Hara in “This World of Tomorrow” at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Nov. 19, 2025
item.description: Jeremy Newton can’t get no satisfaction.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Trump autorizó planes de la CIA para una operación encubierta en Venezuela
item.description: El presidente de EE. UU. dio el visto bueno a posibles operaciones dentro de Venezuela, pero también ha reabierto los canales de comunicación con el gobierno de Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: La siguiente fase de la campaña de presión del gobierno de Trump sobre el gobierno del presidente Nicolás Maduro podría ser un sabotaje o algún tipo de operación cibernética, psicológica o informativa.

item.title: House Rejects Censuring Plaskett For Texts With Epstein In 2019
item.description: Three Republicans voted with nearly every Democrat in the House to defeat an effort to formally reprimand Delegate Stacey Plaskett, Democrat of the Virgin Islands.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro and Robert Jimison

media:content.media:description: Stacey Plaskett, Democrat of the Virgin Islands, during a House Committee on the Judiciary hearing at the Capitol, last year.

item.title: In Nebraska, Makeovers for Buildings That Don’t Price Out the Locals
item.description: In a struggling area of Lincoln, a program pays for repairs and energy efficiency upgrades in rental buildings. In return, landlords must keep rents affordable.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Arin Yoon

media:content.media:credit: Arin Yoon for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Freedom Comes to My Mind’: Saving Family Legacy and Land in South Carolina
item.description: Conservation can be tough when a property is passed down informally over generations with no clear title. A growing effort is helping families sort it all out.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Nora Williams

media:content.media:credit: Nora Willams For The New York Times

item.title: Driving an E.V. Across North Dakota? Thank the Standing Rock Tribe.
item.description: A tribally owned network of chargers will soon be complete, connecting reservations and bridging a gap in the Midwest.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Jaida Grey Eagle

media:content.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times

item.title: In Washington, Birds Are Giving ‘Yelp Reviews’ of Forest Restoration Work
item.description: A collective of land trusts, conservancies and tribes is capturing birdsong with audio gear and A.I. for clues about habitat health.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Meron Menghistab

media:content.media:credit: Meron Menghistab for The New York Times

item.title: Iowa City Made Its Buses Free. Traffic Cleared, and So Did the Air.
item.description: Ridership jumped, people cut back on driving and, over the summer, the city extended the program another year.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Annick Sjobakken

media:content.media:credit: Annick Sjobakken for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Ramps Up Redistricting Pressure on Indiana Republicans
item.description: After the State Senate said it would not take up a new map, President Trump said he would support primary challengers against Republicans who bucked him.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith

media:content.media:description: Gov. Mike Braun of Indiana and other Republicans have argued that redistricting in Indiana was necessary to counter gerrymandering by Democrats in other states.

item.title: Democratic Lawmakers Tell Military to Refuse Illegal Orders
item.description: Six lawmakers, who all served in the military or the intelligence community, released the message in a video. The Trump administration sharply criticized the effort.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Marines and members of the National Guard were deployed to Los Angeles to assist immigration agents this summer.

item.title: Once a Pariah, Saudi Prince Resets U.S. Relations on His Own Terms
item.description: Seven years ago, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman couldn’t visit Washington. When he arrived at the White House on Tuesday, he got F-35s, the world’s fastest chips and the central role in the remaking of the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:description: Mohammed bin Salman, the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, leaving the White House on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: How TikTok Helped Meta Land an Antitrust Victory
item.description: Silicon Valley has increasingly pointed at rapid digital changes to blunt government efforts to rein in its power.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Steve Lohr

media:content.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Federal Trade Commission, which sued Meta five years ago.

item.title: La Cámara de Representantes de EE. UU. aprueba la ley para divulgar los archivos del caso Epstein
item.description: Aunque votaron para exigir la publicación de los archivos, los líderes republicanos desestimaron la medida como un “voto político de exhibición” impulsado por demócratas.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El presidente de la Cámara de Representantes, Mike Johnson, en el Capitolio el martes. La Cámara votó 427 a 1 a favor de un proyecto de ley relativo a los expedientes del Departamento de Justicia sobre el delincuente sexual condenado Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Congress Approves Bill to Release Epstein Files
item.description: Congress approved a bill demanding the Justice Department to release all of the Epstein files. President Trump, who was once friends with Epstein, initially opposed the vote, but caved to pressure and said he would sign the bill.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal and Christina Kelso

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Federal Judge Orders Some Texas Schools to Remove Ten Commandment Posters
item.description: The judge sided with families of students who had argued that the displays infringed on their religious freedom.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Texas law requires school districts to display the Ten Commandments in a “conspicuous location” in each classroom.

item.title: Trump Lauds M.B.S. During White House Visit and Dismisses Khashoggi’s Killing
item.description: President Trump rejected a U.S. intelligence report finding that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman had ordered the murder of a journalist.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers

media:content.media:description: President Trump and Mohammed bin Salman, the crown prince and prime minister of Saudi Arabia, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Republican Clay Higgins Was the Sole Vote Against Releasing the Epstein Files
item.description: The only person in Congress to vote against the bill was a right-wing congressman from Louisiana who is an ardent supporter of President Trump and has espoused conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:description: Representative Clay Higgins, Republican of Louisiana, during a Homeland Security Committee hearing at the Capitol last year.

item.title: N.Y. Doctor Accused of Desecration Can Be Sent to Japan, Court Rules
item.description: A federal appeals court ruled that Masahide Kanayama, a surgeon and practicing Christian, may be extradited to face charges of vandalism.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Japanese authorities said a shrine and temple were daubed with oil, and that they had traced the acts to Masahide Kanayama through surveillance footage.

item.title: At $236 Million, Klimt Piece Is Second Most Expensive Painting Sold at Auction
item.description: At $236.4 million, a portrait by Gustav Klimt is the second most expensive painting at auction, while Maurizio Cattelan’s golden toilet drew $12.1 million.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Julia Halperin

media:content.media:description: Modern art history: The auctioneer at Sotheby’s, Oliver Barker, hammered down a final bid on a portrait of Elisabeth Lederer by Klimt.

item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: The next phase of the Trump administration’s escalating pressure campaign on the government of President Nicolás Maduro could be sabotage or some sort of cyber, psychological or information operations.

item.title: Here’s Who’s Attending Trump’s Dinner for the Saudi Crown Prince: Elon Musk, Cristiano Ronaldo and more.
item.description: The guests at President Trump’s dinner for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia included prominent figures in sports and business.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: J.D. Vance, Not That One, Gets 2 Years in Prison for Threatening the Vice President
item.description: James Donald Vance Jr., of Grand Rapids, Mich., had also threatened President Trump, according to a criminal complaint.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

media:content.media:description: President Trump and Vice President JD Vance on Veterans Day.

item.title: Trump’s Border Czar Threatens More Immigrant Arrests in New York City
item.description: Thomas Homan said that additional federal agents would descend on the city if it did not help with President Trump’s deportation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

media:content.media:description: Thomas Homan, the Trump administration’s border czar, said that he was targeting New York City because of its so-called sanctuary policies.

item.title: Scientists Call for Global Shift Away From Ultraprocessed Foods
item.description: In a sweeping series of papers, scientists have proposed policy reforms, such as taxes on sugary drinks, to improve the food supply.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan

media:content.media:credit: Claire Merchlinsky/The New York Times; Photographs by Getty

item.title: Israeli Airstrike on Refugee Camp in Lebanon Kills at Least 13, Officials Say
item.description: It was one of the deadliest Israeli strikes on Lebanon since a cease-fire with Hezbollah went into effect about a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:description: Members of the Lebanese Army gathered on Tuesday at the entrance of the Ain al-Hilweh refugee camp after an Israeli strike.

item.title: ‘Meet the Cartozians’ Review: Who Gets to Be White in America?
item.description: Talene Monahon’s captivating play uses a 1925 court decision to explore what identity means to Armenians here (a certain reality TV star included).
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez

media:content.media:description: The cast of “Meet the Cartozians,” from left: Will Brill, Tamara Sevunts, Andrea Martin, Raffi Barsoumian and Nael Nacer at the Pershing Square Signature Center in Manhattan.
